G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, which confers jurisdiction upon district courts for actions involving residential landlord-tenant disputes.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the Plaintiff's residence, the subject premises, is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, Massachusetts law provides tenants with the right to quiet enjoyment of their rental unit, prohibiting landlords from engaging in acts or omissions that substantially interfere with a tenant's use and enjoyment of the premises.

In *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (198.proposition: In *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts held that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when their conduct or omissions render the leased premises substantially unsuitable for the purposes for which they are rented.
In *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the meaning of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and adopts the modern Massachusetts rule that liability is based on the natural and probable consequences of the landlord’s acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the premises, rather than subjective intent. That standard is functionally equivalent to saying a landlord breaches the covenant when its conduct or omissions render the premises substantially unsuitable for the purposes for which they are rented, so the case supports the stated proposition even if it does not use that exact phrasing.
In *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights. Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381-383 (1942). Shindler v. Milden, 282 Mass. 32, 33 (1933).”

The Court in *Doe v. New Bedford Housing.raw_text: The Court in *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*, 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
The Court in *Doe v. New Bedford Housing.proposition: The Court in *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*, 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994), affirmed that tenants are entitled to compensation for interference with their quiet enjoyment of the premises caused by the landlord’s unreasonable actions.
The Court in *Doe v. New Bedford Housing.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
The Court in *Doe v. New Bedford Housing.support_reasoning: The court explicitly held that a landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment) where its failure to take measures within its control to address criminal activity on the premises results in serious interference with tenants’ use of the property. It reversed summary judgment on the quiet enjoyment claim and explained that if the landlord “failed to take any action or inadequate action” under circumstances causing serious interference, the tenants would be entitled to judgment and relief. That directly affirms that tenants are entitled to compensation for interference with quiet enjoyment caused by the landlord’s unreasonable omissions.
The Court in *Doe v. New Bedford Housing.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action, despite covenanting that the plaintiffs’ right to quiet enjoyment shall not be interfered with, then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997), reiterated that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to undisturbed use and occupancy and that plaintiffs can recover damages for its violation.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The opinion’s main holding is about the fault standard (at least negligence) required to prove a statutory quiet enjoyment claim and that a lead paint violation alone is not enough. However, in doing so the court squarely characterizes G.L. c. 186, § 14 as codifying the tenant’s common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment and applies it in the context of damages for interference with use and occupancy. While this case focuses more on the liability standard than on the availability of damages, it does reaffirm that § 14 protects tenants’ quiet enjoyment and is a vehicle for recovery when violated.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. In 1973, the statute was rewritten and the requirement of intentional conduct was eliminated; landlords could now be held liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

In *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714,.proposition: In *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 715-718 (1977), the Court held that landlords are responsible for unreasonable interferences with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment, even when caused by third parties under the landlord’s control.
In *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that landlords can be liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where substantial noise and disturbance are caused by another tenant (the lounge) whose activities the landlords had the right and ability to control. The court emphasizes that the landlords created the situation by leasing to the lounge, had contractual control over noise levels, received complaints, and could have abated the problem, and therefore could not avoid responsibility by pointing to the third party’s conduct.
In *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714,.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that, as matter of law, the landlords had a right to control the objectionable noise coming from the lounge and that the judge was warranted in finding as a fact that the landlords could control the objectionable conditions.… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: The dust infiltration into Plaintiff’s unit constitutes a physical intrusion that supports a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment, as upheld in *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184, 200 (1973).
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: This portion of Hemingway is a concurrence/dissent focused on implied warranty of habitability and the effect of State Sanitary Code violations on rent and eviction; it does not discuss dust infiltration, physical intrusions, or the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. Nothing in this excerpt frames code violations or unsanitary conditions as a "physical intrusion" supporting a quiet enjoyment claim. Accordingly, citing this case for the specific proposition that dust infiltration is a physical intrusion supporting breach of quiet enjoyment misstates its holding and reasoning.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: "The opinion of the court holds that the tenants are subject to eviction because of their failure to pay rent, but that their liability for unpaid rent is limited to the reasonable value, if any, of their apartments, considering the alleged violations of the Code. That holding is sufficient to dispose of the only issues raised in these cases, and to that extent I concur with the opinion."

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Massachusetts landlord-tenant laws codified under G.L. c. 239, § 8A provide additional protections to tenants, emphasizing the importance of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential leases.

*Burlington v. District Court*, 382 Mass.proposition: The Defendant’s conduct also constitutes a violation of the implied warranty of habitability described in *Burlington v. District Court*, 382 Mass. 159 (1980), to the extent the dust and persistent disruption affect habitable conditions.
*Burlington v. District Court*, 382 Mass.case_name: Director of the Division of Employment Security v. Fitzgerald
*Burlington v. District Court*, 382 Mass.support_reasoning: This decision is an unemployment benefits case about whether a pregnant employee on maternity leave is in “total unemployment” and whether she voluntarily left work. It does not concern landlord‑tenant law, residential conditions, or any implied warranty of habitability. Citing this case for the proposition that certain dust and disruption violate an implied warranty of habitability misattributes both the subject matter and the holding of the opinion.
*Burlington v. District Court*, 382 Mass.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 151A, § 1 (r) (2), as appearing in St. 1951, c. 763, § 1, describes “total unemployment” thus: “[A]n individual shall be deemed to be in total unemployment in any week in which he performs no wage-earning services whatever, and for which he receives no remuneration, and in which, though capable of and available for work, he is unable to obtain any suitable work.” Thence follows § 29 (a)...
